results.title: [Nicoll Family Home Movie Collection]
results.brief_description:
The Nicoll Family Home Movie Collection is a collection of 16mm home movies made by Alexander (Alex) Nicoll from the 1930s to the 1960s. The films were donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s son Mac Nicoll.

Alex was gifted his camera from a wealthy mentor, Arthur Thomas, who also lent Alex money to establish a business. Alex began a lifelong involvement in the “rag trade”, running an import agency on the third floor at Tasmania House. He was a popular figure in “The Lane”, serving for some years as the President of the Victorian Softgoods Association.

Alex always deeply respected Arthur Thomas, keeping a framed photo of Thomas on his desk until he retired. Thomas was a keen photographer and when he died in the 1930s he left Alex his Agfa 16mm camera, his projector and collapsible screen, all of which Alex frequently used during the 1940s and 1950s. There were films galore: films of family at home and on holidays, of faraway places in his later years and local events. For example, he captured the excitement of the 1956 Olympics in Melbourne with footage of the decorated buildings in the city with the department stores of the era – Foy’s, Buckley’s, Myer, Coles and Woolworths. He was often asked to show his films at family events and other local gatherings.

Alex suffered a serious stroke in 1960, which caused the sale of his business and the end of his photography. He died in 1968 and the film equipment passed to his son, Mac, who continued filming the comings and goings of his young family in the 1960s to the early 1970s. Mac valued the support shown to his father and in his way, supported others by becoming a well-respected teacher.

results.title: [Nicoll Family Home Movies: Reel 5]
results.brief_description:
Filmmaker Alexander Nicoll made a range of home movies in Australia from the 1930s to the 1960s. The family film collection was donated to ACMI by Alexander’s son Mac.

This reel captures the excitement of the 1956 Olympics in Melbourne with footage of the decorated buildings in the city featuring the department stores of the era – Foy’s, Buckley’s, Myer, Coles Store and Woolworths. Also included is a family wedding and scenes from the beach.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 views of Melbourne’s decorated department stores – Foy’s, Buckley’s, Myer, Coles Store (as it was named then) and Woolworths
00:01:42:00 family wedding scenes
00:02:54:00 wedding shots at the church including 1950s fashion style
00:03:24:00 family members at the beach show off the style of the day – striped towels, and a range of clothes from trousers to bathers with ‘shirring’ and sundresses

results.title: Tina Turner in Coober Pedy
results.brief_description: “I love listening to music while I’m working, and the music gives me ideas for the pictures. I might be listening to Tina Turner and that reminds me of when Tina was in the movie Mad Max 3 in the sparkly silver dress. Mad Max is filmed in the Outback and looks just like Indulkana, so I start thinking about what it might be like if Tina came to my community.” -Kaylene Whiskey

results.title: Ariarne Titmus’ coach Dean Boxall on her winning gold
results.brief_description: Australians were in a frenzy of excitement when Ariarne Titmus won gold in the women’s 400m freestyle in her Olympic debut in Tokyo. Managing to dethrone previous Olympic medallist Katie Ledecky, Titmus later spoke of the pain and years of dedication it took to win. Knowing her journey full well, no one else was more ecstatic than her coach, Dean Boxell.
results.title_for_label: Ariarne Titmus’ coach Dean Boxall on her winning gold
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Australians were in a frenzy of excitement when Ariarne Titmus won gold in the women’s 400m freestyle in her Olympic debut in Tokyo. After dethroning defending champion Katie Ledecky, Titmus revealed the years of dedication it took to win, telling Sunrise: “Physically, it’s a lot of training. On the days that I’m at the pool twice a day I could be there up to seven or eight hours and Dean is there a lot longer.”

Knowing her journey full well, no one else was more ecstatic than her coach, Dean Boxell, whose enthusiastic celebration was thrust into the limelight across social media.

Boxell was captured enthusiastically dancing, punching the air, screaming in joy, and yes, air-humping the glass barrier in celebration. His vigorous outpouring almost immediately went viral, spreading across local news, Twitter and Instagram after countless Olympic viewers filmed their TV screens and shared it online. Many were right there with him, finding his gut reaction honest, endearing and typically Australian.

But others found the display over the top and offensive, leading to a backlash from some Twitter users, especially Americans. Was this something that only Australian audiences could understand? Or was this an example of inflated male privilege? Titmus certainly didn’t mind at all and was thrilled to share the moment with her fervently loyal coach, who was inspired by his favourite wrestler from childhood, Ultimate Warrior.

“He is my favourite. I used to wrestle with my brother … I loved the Ultimate Warrior,” he has said.
description_for_label:
This responsive display presents the moment, stories ad memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Australians were in a frenzy of excitement when Ariarne Titmus won gold in the women’s 400m freestyle in her Olympic debut in Tokyo. After dethroning defending champion Katie Ledecky, Titmus revealed the years of dedication it took to win. Knowing her journey full well, no one was more excited than coach Dean Boxell, whose celebration was thrust into the limelight across social media.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Minds → MM-09. Catch of the Day

results.title: Jeff Bezos post-launch brief
results.brief_description:
Following Jeff Bezos’ launch into space on the New Shephard rocket ship, the billionaire took a moment to thank those who had made it possible. The ten-minute, $5.5 billion trip was essentially bankrolled by Amazon customers and employees – the latter of whom are renowned for being criminally overworked and underpaid. During a period of historic inequality, a billionaire blasting off a planet ravaged by the climate crisis and a pandemic seemed tone-deaf at best, villainous at worst.

It also wasn’t lost on many social media users how phallic the New Shephard’s shape seemed to be, generating an avalanche of quips suggesting Bezos was overcompensating for… something. Naturally, the internet didn’t take long to compare the New Shephard to the rocket launched by Dr Evil in Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me. While these jokes may seem throw-away moments of internet culture, they, like others referencing his recent divorce, use humour and absurdity to bring Bezos back down to earth. And the backlash isn’t only against the Amazon founder, but also Richard Branson and Elon Musk, billionaires jostling to beat each other into the stratosphere in a space race that exposes how massive corporations and individuals now possess the resources to do what was once reserved for Cold War superpowers. While Bezos timed the launch on the anniversary of the 1969 Moon landing, many Twitter users noted the disparity between that globally unifying moment and the disillusionment of watching a man who could end poverty take an intergalactic joyride.

results.title: Eye of fire
results.brief_description: A gas leak in an underwater pipeline caused an oceanic fireball dubbed ‘The Eye of Fire’ in the Gulf of Mexico. The state owned company is investigating the causes.

constellations_other.name: Deep blue
constellations_other.description: Go deep on an exploration of real world oceans and those rendered by pixels and creatures made from plastics.

results.title_for_label: ‘Eye of fire’ in the Gulf of Mexico
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

In horrific scenes that seemed more like footage from an action movie than the real world, the ocean was literally on fire on 3 July 2021 in the Gulf of Mexico. The huge fireball blazing across the sea surface was caused by a gas leak from an underwater pipeline, which social media users dubbed ‘the eye of fire’. The video was shared across the internet as further evidence of the environmental tolls of capitalism and the irresponsibility of fossil fuel companies plundering natural resources and producing unnatural results.
description_for_label:
This responsive display presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

In astonishing scenes, the ocean was literally on fire on 3 July 2021 in the Gulf of Mexico. The fireball blazing across the sea surface, dubbed the ‘eye of fire’ by social media users, was caused by an underwater gas leak from a pipeline. The video spread across the internet as further evidence of fossil fuel companies plundering natural resources and producing unnatural results.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Minds → MM-09. Catch of the Day

results.title: 9 News Covid-19 press conference
results.brief_description: At a recent NSW Covid-19 press conference, authorities revealed they’d fined two nudists for sunbaking outside in defiance of stay-at-home-orders. While that’s revealed to be contentious (they were inside the border), the fact that the duo needed to be rescued after being startled by a deer and getting lost in a forest brought some light-heartedness to the dour proceedings. The Auslan interpretation of the story also tickled Twitter users.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

At a recent NSW Covid-19 press conference, authorities revealed they’d fined two nudists for sunbaking outside in defiance of stay-at-home orders. While that’s revealed to be contentious (they were inside the designated area), the fact that the duo needed to be rescued after being startled by a deer and getting lost in a forest brought some much-needed light-heartedness to the otherwise dour proceedings.

As ABC producer Justin Stevens’ simple caption of ‘2021’ highlights, we’re living through an unusual and absurd age when these types of things seem the norm. Not to mention the lively Auslan interpretation of ‘sunbathing naked’ and ‘deer’, which was quickly turned into a meme and propelled the virality of the moment across social media.

Aside from being a humorous moment, it also highlighted the importance and highly skilled work of the unnamed interpreter, with one Twitter user commenting, “The woman who managed to do the Auslan today deserves credit.”

As Pedestrian TV reported: “Despite all the anxiety-riddled brouhaha that the global pandemic has beset upon us all, one of the great (and few) shining lights has been the, well, light shining upon the string of Auslan interpreters who have gamely stood next to Premiers and Chief Health Officers and interpreted complex, often rapid-fire information on the fly.”

These live-streamed press conferences also offer the public the opportunity to see the production of media and politics, allowing users to interact with breaking news and opine in real-time on social media, rather than just passively receive announcements from the government.
description_for_label:
This responsive display presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

At a recent NSW Covid-19 press conference, authorities revealed they’d fined two nudists for sunbaking outside in defiance of stay-at-home orders. While that’s now contentious (they were inside the border), the fact that the duo needed to be rescued after being startled by a deer and getting lost in a forest brought some light-heartedness to the dour proceedings. Keep an eye on the Auslan interpretation, which also tickled Twitter users.

results.title: The Gods of Tiny Things
results.credit_line:
Deborah Kelly

Two-channel digital animation, colour, sound

ACMI Collection

Collage figures: Joanne Albany, Alana Ambados, Kate Andrews, Justin Ashworth, Kathryn Bird, Karen Golland, Amanda Holt, Deborah Kelly, Kath Lim, Lex Lindsay, Megan Rushton, Rie Tamaoke, Anna Tregloan
results.brief_description: Deborah Kelly’s The Gods of Tiny Things is a vast, microscopic Eden teeming with deities born from the pages of old magazines and encyclopaedias, creating an exquisite collage of grotesque beauty and new mythologies.

constellations_primary.name: Speculative futures, sci-fi worlds and environmental disaster
constellations_primary.description: Deborah Kelly's The Gods of Tiny Things explores extinction and the climate crisis, the scars of colonialism, and the political shift to the right around the world through collage and imagined futures, much like these sci-fi, animated and computer-generated artworks.

results.description:
“This work is blessed by the powers of the animator, musicians and collagists. Having such creative collaborators is the treasure of my life” – Deborah Kelly

The Gods of Tiny Things is a vast, microscopic Eden teeming with deities born from the pages of old magazines and encyclopedias, creating an exquisite collage of grotesque beauty and new mythologies. Combining the divine, mundane and profane, these celestial creations animate a kaleidoscopic symbology that explores extinction and the climate crisis, the scars of colonialism, and the political shift to the right around the world, while simultaneously revelling in the persistence of pleasure, desire and life. Created at ‘collage camp’ at Bundanon on beautiful Yuin Country, this collaborative work is a poetic and urgent warning.

Deborah Kelly is a Sydney-based artist whose works have been shown around Australia, and in the Biennales of Singapore, Sydney, Thessaloniki, TarraWarra and Venice. Her projects across media are concerned with lineages of representation, politics and history in public exchange, and practices of collectivity on small and large scale, both fleeting and durational. Her newest works experiment with models of sustained creative collaboration between strangers. Kelly’s moving image artworks have been shown around the world, in galleries, cinemas and projected onto rock formations, buildings and clouds.
description_for_label:
“This work is blessed by the powers of the animator, musicians and collagists. Having such creative collaborators is the treasure of my life” – Deborah Kelly

results.title: Israeli air raid on building housing international media
results.material_description: screen recording of @AJEnglish’s Twitter Digital screen recording from @AJEnglish's Twitter
results.brief_description: In the sixth consecutive day of hostilities between Israel and Hamas, Israeli airstrikes bombed a 15-storey block in the heart of Gaza that housed private homes and workplaces as well as the offices of media organisations Al Jazeera and the Associated Press. Defending the attack, Israeli officials stated that Hamas was operating an intelligence cell out in the building yet AP executive editor Sally Buzbee has called for an independent inquiry into the strike stating that this attack destroyed the ability for news reporting in the territory vehemently fighting for the world’s right to know. “This is an important story and because of the actions yesterday, the world is going to know less.”
results.title_for_label: Israeli air raid on building housing international media
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

In the sixth consecutive day of attacks between Israeli and Palestinian forces, Israel bombed a 15-storey block in Gaza City claiming that Hamas was operating an intelligence cell in the building. Along with the private homes and workplaces in the building, it housed the offices of media organisations Al Jazeera and the Associated Press who were given advance warning of the bombing. Al Jazeera broadcast live, in real time, footage of their own offices being destroyed which went viral changing the international coverage of the ongoing Israel-Palestine conflict. AP executive editor Sally Buzbee has called for an independent inquiry into the strike, stating “This is an important story and because of the actions yesterday, the world is going to know less.”
description_for_label: In the sixth consecutive day of attacks between Israeli and Palestinian forces, Israel bombed an office building in Gaza City, claiming that Hamas was operating an intelligence cell in the building. Along with private homes and workplaces, the building housed the offices of Al Jazeera and the Associated Press, who were given advance warning of the bombing. Al Jazeera and the AP broadcast live footage of their own offices being destroyed, which went viral and changed the international coverage of the conflict.

results.title: Convicted on all charges
results.brief_description: The murder of George Floyd by a Minneapolis police officer was captured on video and incited waves of protests in the US and around the world. When the jury swiftly and unanimously convicted the officer of all charges, huge crowds gathered to pay their respects to Floyd at the intersection where he took his last breaths. Minnesota’s attorney general, Keith Ellison welcomed the conviction stating, “This verdict reminds us that we must make enduring… enduring systemic, societal change.” Three other officers face trial for aiding and abetting murder and manslaughter. Key to securing the conviction was a video taken by a bystander.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

The murder of George Floyd by a Minneapolis police officer was captured on video and incited waves of protests in the US and around the world. When the jury swiftly and unanimously convicted the officer of all charges, huge crowds gathered to pay their respects to Floyd at the intersection where he took his last breaths. Three other officers face trial for aiding and abetting murder and manslaughter.
